title: 115_hr1957
content: The "Safe Schools Improvement Act of 2017" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Congress acknowledges that bullying and harassment in schools can have serious negative effects on students' physical and psychological health, leading to academic underachievement and high dropout rates. These behaviors include physical violence, name-calling, intimidation, social exclusion, and cyberbullying. Students are targeted for bullying based on various factors like race, gender, and disability. Schools with anti-bullying policies see increased reporting and intervention, reducing incidents. Some experience psychological bullying, causing harm. Interventions like Positive Behavior Interventions and Supports (PBIS) can help minimize bullying and harassment in schools, creating a positive and safe environment for students. 85 percent of Americans support a Federal law to require schools to address these issues. According to a poll, 85 percent of Americans support a Federal law to enforce specific rules in schools to prevent bullying. Students, parents, educators, and policymakers are calling for action to address the national crisis of bullying and harassment. The Safe Schools Improvement Act aims to address bullying and harassment in public elementary and secondary schools by implementing anti-bullying policies. The Safe Schools Improvement Act requires states receiving grants to mandate local educational agencies to establish policies preventing severe, persistent, or pervasive bullying and harassment that limits a student's participation or creates a hostile educational environment. The Safe Schools Improvement Act mandates policies at public schools to prevent bullying and harassment based on various characteristics like race, color, national origin, sex, disability, sexual orientation, gender identity, or religion. The Safe Schools Improvement Act requires public schools to have policies preventing bullying and harassment based on specific characteristics, including race, color, national origin, sex, disability, sexual orientation, gender identity, religion, homelessness, or being a child of a member of the Armed Forces. Schools must provide annual notice of prohibited conduct and grievance procedures for complaints. The Safe Schools Improvement Act mandates public schools to have policies addressing bullying and harassment based on specific characteristics. These policies must include designated officials for receiving complaints and establish timelines for resolution. Schools are required to collect and publicly report accurate data on incidents at the school and district levels while ensuring the confidentiality of victims and perpetrators. Positive and preventative approaches to addressing such conduct should be encouraged. The agency must ensure that victims and perpetrators of misconduct remain anonymous. Positive and preventative school discipline approaches should be promoted to reduce student removal from instruction and prevent disproportionate punishment. State reports must be submitted by the chief executive officer of a State receiving a grant under this title, in cooperation with the State educational agency. The report should include information reported by local educational agencies and describe the State's plans to support local educational agency efforts in addressing prohibited conduct. The Secretary conducts biennial evaluations of anti-bullying programs in schools, collects data on prohibited conduct, and submits reports to the President and Congress every two years. Congress receives a report on the evaluation findings, including data from subsection (a) and (b), as well as information submitted by States under section 4703. "SEC. 4705. EFFECT ON OTHER LAWS." The section states that federal and state nondiscrimination laws remain valid and unaffected by the regulations outlined in this part. These laws include title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, and the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. The obligations imposed by this part are additional to those imposed by the mentioned laws. The regulations outlined in this part do not affect federal and state nondiscrimination laws, including title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, and the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. Nothing in this part changes legal standards or rights under other federal laws protecting freedom of speech or expression. The text outlines that states and local entities can enact laws to prevent bullying or harassment of students as long as they are not inconsistent with the regulations in this part. The table of contents includes sections on the purpose, anti-bullying policies, state reports, evaluation, and the rule of construction.
